citation.abstract: Reducing healthcare-associated infections (HCAI) has been a priority in the UK over recent decades and this has been reflected in interventions focussing on improving hygiene procedures.
citation.title: The impact of national‐level interventions to improve hygiene on the incidence of irritant contact dermatitis in healthcare workers: changes in incidence from 1996 to 2012 and interrupted times series analysis

news.title: Focus on handwashing in hospitals has led to rise in staff dermatitis
news.summary: The incidence of dermatitis has increased 4.5 times in healthcare workers following increased hand hygiene as a drive to reduce infections, such as MRSA, has kicked in, claim UK researchers.

news.title: Hand washing focus in hospitals has led to rise in worker dermatitis
news.summary: A new study from The University of Manchester has revealed that the incidence of dermatitis has increased 4.5 times in health care workers following increased hand hygiene as a drive to reduce infections such as MRSA has kicked in.

news.title: Dermatitis Rates Increasing As Hospital Hand Washing Policies Seek To Sanitize
news.summary: Patients aren't getting infected to nearly the degree they used to be, and hospital workers' hands are suffering the consequences.

news.title: Increased hand washing has led to rise in dermatitis among frontline hospital staff
news.summary: A new study reveals there has been a more than four-fold increase in dermatitis among health workers following increased hand hygiene to reduce hospital infections like MRSA.

news.title: 450 Percent Increase Of Dermatitis In Hospital Staff Linked To Increased Hand Washing Since 1996
news.summary: Dermatitis among UK hospital workers has increased by 450 percent since 1996, according to a new study from researchers at the Institute of Population Health at The University of Manchester. While work-related dermatitis decreased in other fields, hospital

news.title: Widespread dermatitis in UK hospitals
news.summary: Better hand hygiene among hospital staff has come at the expense of increasing skin problems and infection rates

news.title: Increased hand washing is causing harm to healthcare workers
news.summary: As part of the improvements in hospitals to minimize the rate of healthcare acquired infections affecting patients, healthcare workers have been told to frequently wash their hands. One downside is an increase in skin conditions.

news.title: Frequent hand hygiene increased incidence of dermatitis in HCWs
